student_allergies.name: Pollen Allergy
student_allergies.description: An allergic reaction to pollen grains released by plants during pollination.
student_allergies.management: Avoiding exposure to pollen, using air purifiers, taking antihistamines, and immunotherapy.

student_allergies.name: Food Allergy (e.g., Peanut)
student_allergies.description: An adverse immune response to certain proteins found in peanuts, leading to various symptoms.
student_allergies.management: Strict avoidance of peanuts and peanut products, carrying epinephrine auto-injectors, and seeking emergency medical care if exposed.

student_allergies.name: Drug Allergy (e.g., Penicillin)
student_allergies.description: An adverse reaction to certain medications, such as penicillin, due to the immune system's response.
symptoms: Swelling of the face, lips, or tongue
student_allergies.management: Avoiding the specific medication and informing healthcare providers of the allergy to prevent future exposure.

student_allergies.name: Insect Sting Allergy (e.g., Bee Sting)
student_allergies.description: An allergic reaction to venom injected by stinging insects, such as bees or wasps.
symptoms: Localized swelling, redness, and pain at the sting site
Hives or itching in other areas of the body
student_allergies.management: Avoiding insect stings, carrying epinephrine auto-injectors, wearing protective clothing, and seeking immediate medical attention if stung.

student_allergies.name: Animal Allergy (e.g., Pet Dander)
student_allergies.description: An allergic reaction to proteins found in the skin cells, saliva, or urine of animals, such as cats or dogs.
student_allergies.management: Reducing exposure to animals, keeping pets out of the bedroom, using air purifiers, and taking antihistamines.

student_allergies.name: Latex Allergy
student_allergies.description: An allergic reaction to proteins found in natural rubber latex, commonly found in medical gloves, balloons, and condoms.
student_allergies.management: Avoiding latex products, using latex-free alternatives, and informing healthcare providers to prevent exposure.

student_allergies.name: Mold Allergy
student_allergies.description: An allergic reaction to mold spores commonly found in damp environments, such as bathrooms, basements, and kitchens.
student_allergies.management: Reducing indoor humidity levels, fixing water leaks, using air purifiers, and avoiding outdoor activities during high mold counts.

student_allergies.name: Hay Fever (Allergic Rhinitis)
student_allergies.description: An allergic reaction to airborne allergens such as pollen, dust mites, or pet dander, causing inflammation of the nasal passages.
student_allergies.management: Avoiding allergens, using nasal sprays or antihistamines, and allergen immunotherapy in severe cases.

student_allergies.name: Shellfish Allergy
student_allergies.description: An allergic reaction to proteins found in shellfish, including crustaceans like shrimp, crab, and lobster, as well as mollusks like clams, mussels, and oysters.
student_allergies.management: Avoiding shellfish and related products, carrying epinephrine auto-injectors, and seeking immediate medical attention if exposed.

student_allergies.name: Dust Mite Allergy
student_allergies.description: An allergic reaction to tiny bugs called dust mites, commonly found in bedding, upholstered furniture, and carpeting.
student_allergies.management: Using allergen-proof bedding, vacuuming regularly, reducing indoor humidity, and using air purifiers.
